comment_text.mn14:2.1: Mahānāma was the brother of Anuruddha and Ānanda (Kd 17:1.1.3) which, according to the commentary, makes the Buddha his cousin. He remained in the lay life as a devoted and generous follower, keenly interested in developing his practice. The early texts do not record any occasion of his awakening. However, the commentarial claim that he was a once-returner is supported by passages such as SN 55.22:2.3 and SN 55.21:3.6 that suggest he was indeed a noble disciple.
comment_text.mn14:2.8: As in the opening of the previous discourse, he exhibits curiosity and openness to inquiry.
comment_text.mn14:4.2: The “rapture and bliss that are apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities” includes the first and second jhānas. The text is in present tense: they do not attain jhāna, not they have never attained jhāna. In order to realize the noble truths, Mahānāma must, of course, have practiced the noble eightfold path, which includes jhāna. Indeed, at AN 3.73:1.6 Mahānāma said he understood that in the Buddha’s teaching, “Knowledge is for those with immersion, not those without immersion.” However, a stream-enterer and a once-returner have not fully given up the underlying attachment to sensual pleasures, so unless they are dedicated to regular meditation following that realization, it is possible for their mental clarity to deteriorate and sensual desires to return. It seems that the temptations and business of the lay life had distracted Mahānāma from his meditation.
comment_text.mn14:4.3: The Pali is expressed in a double negative: “they are not one who does not return”.
comment_text.mn14:5.6: The phrasing of this passage echoes that of the first sermon (SN 56.11:9.1).
comment_text.mn14:15.2: A large open area where the Buddha taught occasionally (SN 8.10), but it is most famous as the place the monks Godhika (SN 4.23) and Vakkali took their lives (SN 22.87). | The practice of constant standing was formerly undertaken by the Bodhisatta (MN 12:45.9).
comment_text.mn14:16.1: The Buddha reports a similar, but more detailed, conversation with Jains at MN 101.
comment_text.mn14:16.2: Even with his own extensive experience in such practices, the Buddha still asks.
comment_text.mn14:17.2: The Jain leader Mahāvīra Vardhamāna is known as Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta in Pali texts. He is regarded as the 24th supreme leader of the Jains, although only he and his predecessor Pārśvanātha (not mentioned in the Pali) are historical. Nigaṇṭha means “knotless” (i.e. without attachments); it is a term for a Jain ascetic. Nātaputta indicates his clan the Ñātikas (Sanskrit jñātiputra; Prākrit nāyaputta). The Pali tradition has confused ñāti (“family”) with nāṭa (“dancer”). Thus Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta means “the Jain monk of the Ñātika clan”.
comment_text.mn14:17.3: The Buddha denied possessing such omniscience; rather, he knows the three knowledges (MN 71:5.5). Nonetheless, he can be poetically considered as “all-knowing” (Thag 2.6:1.4, Thag 16.1:18.1, Thag 1.69:1.2), since he understands the “all” that is the six senses (SN 35.28).
comment_text.mn14:17.5: The Buddha emphasized understanding kamma and relinquishing the causes of new kamma, rather than wearing away the unknowable mass of past kamma. | Mahāvīra’s emphasis on bad karma of the past presages the modern usage where karma is evoked when something inescapably bad happens.
comment_text.mn14:17.8: The past participle with future tense (nijjiṇṇaṁ bhavissati) indicates a future perfect sense, “will have been worn away”.
comment_text.mn14:19.8: This point is argued in more detail at MN 101:12.2 ff. | “Cruel livelihood” (kurūrakammantā) is defined at MN 51:9.2, etc.
comment_text.mn14:20.1: At MN 85:10.2 the Buddha says that he too held this belief while still an unenlightened Bodhisatta. Thus not only were his austerities identical with the Jains, so were his beliefs. The Jain text Sūyagaḍa (known in Sanskrit as Sūtrakṛtāṅga) 1.3.4.6 rejects the view that pleasure is gained through pleasure, attributing it to those who disdain the noble path, which its commentary identifies with Buddhists.
comment_text.mn14:20.2: With their path emphasizing painful austerity, there is little to support the idea that the Jains practiced meditation in the Buddhist sense, and certainly not the deep pleasure of jhāna.
comment_text.mn14:20.7: He holds them to the same standard that he himself has already demonstrated: don’t make assumptions, ask.
comment_text.mn14:21.19: The Buddha sat for seven days after his awakening (Ud 1.1:1.3), an achievement also attested for disciples such as Mahākassapa (Ud 3.7:1.3) and the nun Uttamā (Thig 3.2:3.3).

root_text.mn14:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṁ nigrodhārāme.
root_text.mn14:2.1: Atha kho mahānāmo sakko yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho mahānāmo sakko bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn14:2.2: “dīgharattāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavatā evaṁ dhammaṁ desitaṁ ājānāmi:
root_text.mn14:2.3: ‘lobho cittassa upakkileso, doso cittassa upakkileso, moho cittassa upakkileso’ti.
root_text.mn14:2.4: Evañcāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavatā dhammaṁ desitaṁ ājānāmi:
root_text.mn14:2.5: ‘lobho cittassa upakkileso, doso cittassa upakkileso, moho cittassa upakkileso’ti.
root_text.mn14:2.6: Atha ca pana me ekadā lobhadhammāpi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti, dosadhammāpi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti, mohadhammāpi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti.
root_text.mn14:2.8: ‘kosu nāma me dhammo ajjhattaṁ appahīno yena me ekadā lobhadhammāpi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti, dosadhammāpi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti, mohadhammāpi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhantī’”ti.
root_text.mn14:3.1: “So eva kho te, mahānāma, dhammo ajjhattaṁ appahīno yena te ekadā lobhadhammāpi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti, dosadhammāpi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti, mohadhammāpi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti.
root_text.mn14:3.2: So ca hi te, mahānāma, dhammo ajjhattaṁ pahīno abhavissa, na tvaṁ agāraṁ ajjhāvaseyyāsi, na kāme paribhuñjeyyāsi.
root_text.mn14:3.3: Yasmā ca kho te, mahānāma, so eva dhammo ajjhattaṁ appahīno tasmā tvaṁ agāraṁ ajjhāvasasi, kāme paribhuñjasi.
root_text.mn14:4.1: ‘Appassādā kāmā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo’ti—
root_text.mn14:4.2: iti cepi, mahānāma, ariyasāvakassa yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṁ hoti, so ca aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehi pītisukhaṁ nādhigacchati, aññaṁ vā tato santataraṁ;
root_text.mn14:4.3: atha kho so neva tāva anāvaṭṭī kāmesu hoti.
root_text.mn14:4.4: Yato ca kho, mahānāma, ariyasāvakassa ‘appassādā kāmā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo’ti—evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṁ hoti, so ca aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehi pītisukhaṁ adhigacchati aññaṁ vā tato santataraṁ;
root_text.mn14:4.5: atha kho so anāvaṭṭī kāmesu hoti.
root_text.mn14:5.1: Mayhampi kho, mahānāma, pubbeva sambodhā, anabhisambuddhassa bodhisattasseva sato,
root_text.mn14:5.2: ‘appassādā kāmā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo’ti—evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṁ hoti,
root_text.mn14:5.3: so ca aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehi pītisukhaṁ nājjhagamaṁ, aññaṁ vā tato santataraṁ;
root_text.mn14:5.4: atha khvāhaṁ neva tāva anāvaṭṭī kāmesu paccaññāsiṁ.
root_text.mn14:5.5: Yato ca kho me, mahānāma, ‘appassādā kāmā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo’ti—evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṁ ahosi, so ca aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehi pītisukhaṁ ajjhagamaṁ, aññaṁ vā tato santataraṁ;
root_text.mn14:6.4: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā;
root_text.mn14:6.8: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā—
root_text.mn14:6.10: Yaṁ kho, mahānāma, ime pañca kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṁ somanassaṁ—
root_text.mn14:7.2: Idha, mahānāma, kulaputto yena sippaṭṭhānena jīvikaṁ kappeti—
root_text.mn14:7.3: yadi muddāya yadi gaṇanāya yadi saṅkhānena yadi kasiyā yadi vaṇijjāya yadi gorakkhena yadi issatthena yadi rājaporisena yadi sippaññatarena,
root_text.mn14:7.4: sītassa purakkhato uṇhassa purakkhato ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassehi rissamāno khuppipāsāya mīyamāno;
root_text.mn14:7.5: ayampi, mahānāma, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
root_text.mn14:8.1: Tassa ce, mahānāma, kulaputtassa evaṁ uṭṭhahato ghaṭato vāyamato te bhogā nābhinipphajjanti,
root_text.mn14:8.2: so socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṁ kandati sammohaṁ āpajjati ‘moghaṁ vata me uṭṭhānaṁ, aphalo vata me vāyāmo’ti.
root_text.mn14:8.3: Ayampi, mahānāma, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
root_text.mn14:9.1: Tassa ce, mahānāma, kulaputtassa evaṁ uṭṭhahato ghaṭato vāyamato te bhogā abhinipphajjanti.
root_text.mn14:9.2: So tesaṁ bhogānaṁ ārakkhādhikaraṇaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti:
root_text.mn14:9.3: ‘kinti me bhoge neva rājāno hareyyuṁ, na corā hareyyuṁ, na aggi daheyya, na udakaṁ vaheyya, na appiyā vā dāyādā hareyyun’ti.
root_text.mn14:9.4: Tassa evaṁ ārakkhato gopayato te bhoge rājāno vā haranti, corā vā haranti, aggi vā dahati, udakaṁ vā vahati, appiyā vā dāyādā haranti.
root_text.mn14:9.5: So socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṁ kandati sammohaṁ āpajjati:
root_text.mn14:9.7: Ayampi, mahānāma, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
root_text.mn14:10.1: Puna caparaṁ, mahānāma, kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu rājānopi rājūhi vivadanti, khattiyāpi khattiyehi vivadanti, brāhmaṇāpi brāhmaṇehi vivadanti, gahapatīpi gahapatīhi vivadanti, mātāpi puttena vivadati, puttopi mātarā vivadati, pitāpi puttena vivadati, puttopi pitarā vivadati, bhātāpi bhātarā vivadati, bhātāpi bhaginiyā vivadati, bhaginīpi bhātarā vivadati, sahāyopi sahāyena vivadati.
root_text.mn14:10.2: Te tattha kalahaviggahavivādāpannā aññamaññaṁ pāṇīhipi upakkamanti, leḍḍūhipi upakkamanti, daṇḍehipi upakkamanti, satthehipi upakkamanti.
root_text.mn14:10.3: Te tattha maraṇampi nigacchanti, maraṇamattampi dukkhaṁ.
root_text.mn14:10.4: Ayampi, mahānāma, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
root_text.mn14:11.1: Puna caparaṁ, mahānāma, kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu asicammaṁ gahetvā, dhanukalāpaṁ sannayhitvā, ubhatobyūḷhaṁ saṅgāmaṁ pakkhandanti usūsupi khippamānesu, sattīsupi khippamānāsu, asīsupi vijjotalantesu.
root_text.mn14:11.2: Te tattha usūhipi vijjhanti, sattiyāpi vijjhanti, asināpi sīsaṁ chindanti.
root_text.mn14:11.3: Te tattha maraṇampi nigacchanti, maraṇamattampi dukkhaṁ.
root_text.mn14:11.4: Ayampi, mahānāma, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
root_text.mn14:12.1: Puna caparaṁ, mahānāma, kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu asicammaṁ gahetvā, dhanukalāpaṁ sannayhitvā, addāvalepanā upakāriyo pakkhandanti usūsupi khippamānesu, sattīsupi khippamānāsu, asīsupi vijjotalantesu.
root_text.mn14:12.2: Te tattha usūhipi vijjhanti, sattiyāpi vijjhanti, chakaṇakāyapi osiñcanti, abhivaggenapi omaddanti, asināpi sīsaṁ chindanti.
root_text.mn14:12.3: Te tattha maraṇampi nigacchanti, maraṇamattampi dukkhaṁ.
root_text.mn14:12.4: Ayampi, mahānāma, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
root_text.mn14:13.1: Puna caparaṁ, mahānāma, kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu sandhimpi chindanti, nillopampi haranti, ekāgārikampi karonti, paripanthepi tiṭṭhanti, paradārampi gacchanti.
root_text.mn14:13.2: Tamenaṁ rājāno gahetvā vividhā kammakāraṇā kārenti—
root_text.mn14:13.3: kasāhipi tāḷenti, vettehipi tāḷenti, aḍḍhadaṇḍakehipi tāḷenti; hatthampi chindanti, pādampi chindanti, hatthapādampi chindanti, kaṇṇampi chindanti, nāsampi chindanti, kaṇṇanāsampi chindanti; bilaṅgathālikampi karonti, saṅkhamuṇḍikampi karonti, rāhumukhampi karonti, jotimālikampi karonti, hatthapajjotikampi karonti, erakavattikampi karonti, cīrakavāsikampi karonti, eṇeyyakampi karonti, baḷisamaṁsikampi karonti, kahāpaṇikampi karonti, khārāpatacchikampi karonti, palighaparivattikampi karonti, palālapīṭhakampi karonti, tattenapi telena osiñcanti, sunakhehipi khādāpenti, jīvantampi sūle uttāsenti, asināpi sīsaṁ chindanti.
root_text.mn14:13.4: Te tattha maraṇampi nigacchanti, maraṇamattampi dukkhaṁ.
root_text.mn14:13.5: Ayampi, mahānāma, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
root_text.mn14:14.1: Puna caparaṁ, mahānāma, kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu kāyena duccaritaṁ caranti, vācāya duccaritaṁ caranti, manasā duccaritaṁ caranti.
root_text.mn14:14.2: Te kāyena duccaritaṁ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṁ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṁ caritvā, kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā, apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjanti.
root_text.mn14:14.3: Ayampi, mahānāma, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo samparāyiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
root_text.mn14:15.1: Ekamidāhaṁ, mahānāma, samayaṁ rājagahe viharāmi gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
root_text.mn14:15.2: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā nigaṇṭhā isigilipasse kāḷasilāyaṁ ubbhaṭṭhakā honti āsanapaṭikkhittā, opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti.
root_text.mn14:16.1: Atha khvāhaṁ, mahānāma, sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena isigilipasse kāḷasilā yena te nigaṇṭhā tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā te nigaṇṭhe etadavocaṁ:
root_text.mn14:16.2: ‘kiṁ nu tumhe, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, ubbhaṭṭhakā āsanapaṭikkhittā, opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayathā’ti?
root_text.mn14:17.1: Evaṁ vutte, mahānāma, te nigaṇṭhā maṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn14:17.2: ‘nigaṇṭho, āvuso, nāṭaputto sabbaññū sabbadassāvī aparisesaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paṭijānāti:
root_text.mn14:17.3: “carato ca me tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satataṁ samitaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paccupaṭṭhitan”ti.
root_text.mn14:17.5: “atthi kho vo, nigaṇṭhā, pubbe pāpakammaṁ kataṁ, taṁ imāya kaṭukāya dukkarakārikāya nijjīretha;
root_text.mn14:17.6: yaṁ panettha etarahi kāyena saṁvutā vācāya saṁvutā manasā saṁvutā taṁ āyatiṁ pāpassa kammassa akaraṇaṁ;
root_text.mn14:17.7: iti purāṇānaṁ kammānaṁ tapasā byantibhāvā, navānaṁ kammānaṁ akaraṇā, āyatiṁ anavassavo;
root_text.mn14:17.8: āyatiṁ anavassavā kammakkhayo, kammakkhayā dukkhakkhayo, dukkhakkhayā vedanākkhayo, vedanākkhayā sabbaṁ dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ bhavissatī”ti.
root_text.mn14:17.9: Tañca panamhākaṁ ruccati ceva khamati ca, tena camha attamanā’ti.
root_text.mn14:18.1: Evaṁ vutte, ahaṁ, mahānāma, te nigaṇṭhe etadavocaṁ:
root_text.mn14:18.6: akaramheva mayaṁ pubbe pāpakammaṁ na nākaramhā’ti?
root_text.mn14:18.9: evarūpaṁ vā evarūpaṁ vā pāpakammaṁ akaramhā’ti?
root_text.mn14:18.12: ettakaṁ vā dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ, ettakaṁ vā dukkhaṁ nijjīretabbaṁ, ettakamhi vā dukkhe nijjiṇṇe sabbaṁ dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ bhavissatī’ti?
root_text.mn14:18.15: diṭṭheva dhamme akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pahānaṁ, kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ upasampadan’ti?
root_text.mn14:19.1: ‘Iti kira tumhe, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, na jānātha—
root_text.mn14:19.2: ahuvamheva mayaṁ pubbe na nāhuvamhāti, na jānātha—
root_text.mn14:19.3: akaramheva mayaṁ pubbe pāpakammaṁ na nākaramhāti, na jānātha—
root_text.mn14:19.4: evarūpaṁ vā evarūpaṁ vā pāpakammaṁ akaramhāti, na jānātha—
root_text.mn14:19.5: ettakaṁ vā dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ, ettakaṁ vā dukkhaṁ nijjīretabbaṁ, ettakamhi vā dukkhe nijjiṇṇe sabbaṁ dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ bhavissatīti.
root_text.mn14:19.7: diṭṭheva dhamme akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pahānaṁ, kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ upasampadaṁ.
root_text.mn14:19.8: Evaṁ sante, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, ye loke luddā lohitapāṇino kurūrakammantā manussesu paccājātā te nigaṇṭhesu pabbajantī’ti?
root_text.mn14:20.1: ‘Na kho, āvuso gotama, sukhena sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ, dukkhena kho sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ;
root_text.mn14:20.2: sukhena cāvuso gotama, sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ abhavissa, rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro sukhaṁ adhigaccheyya, rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro sukhavihāritaro āyasmatā gotamenā’ti.
root_text.mn14:20.4: “na kho, āvuso gotama, sukhena sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ, dukkhena kho sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ;
root_text.mn14:20.5: sukhena cāvuso gotama, sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ abhavissa, rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro sukhaṁ adhigaccheyya, rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro sukhavihāritaro āyasmatā gotamenā”ti.
root_text.mn14:20.7: “ko nu kho āyasmantānaṁ sukhavihāritaro rājā vā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro āyasmā vā gotamo”ti?
root_text.mn14:20.8: Addhāvuso gotama, amhehi sahasā appaṭisaṅkhā vācā bhāsitā, na kho, āvuso gotama, sukhena sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ, dukkhena kho sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ;
root_text.mn14:20.9: sukhena cāvuso gotama, sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ abhavissa, rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro sukhaṁ adhigaccheyya, rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro sukhavihāritaro āyasmatā gotamenāti.
root_text.mn14:20.10: Api ca tiṭṭhatetaṁ, idānipi mayaṁ āyasmantaṁ gotamaṁ pucchāma:
root_text.mn14:20.11: “ko nu kho āyasmantānaṁ sukhavihāritaro rājā vā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro āyasmā vā gotamo”ti?
root_text.mn14:21.1: Tena hāvuso nigaṇṭhā, tumheva tattha paṭipucchissāmi, yathā vo khameyya tathā naṁ byākareyyātha.
root_text.mn14:21.2: Taṁ kiṁ maññathāvuso nigaṇṭhā, pahoti rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro,
root_text.mn14:21.3: aniñjamāno kāyena, abhāsamāno vācaṁ, satta rattindivāni ekantasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedī viharitun’ti?
root_text.mn14:21.5: ‘Taṁ kiṁ maññathāvuso nigaṇṭhā, pahoti rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro,
root_text.mn14:21.6: aniñjamāno kāyena, abhāsamāno vācaṁ, cha rattindivāni …pe…
root_text.mn14:21.13: ‘Ahaṁ kho, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, pahomi aniñjamāno kāyena, abhāsamāno vācaṁ, ekaṁ rattindivaṁ ekantasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedī viharituṁ.
root_text.mn14:21.14: Ahaṁ kho, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, pahomi aniñjamāno kāyena, abhāsamāno vācaṁ, dve rattindivāni …
root_text.mn14:21.20: Taṁ kiṁ maññathāvuso nigaṇṭhā, evaṁ sante ko sukhavihāritaro rājā vā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro ahaṁ vā’ti?
root_text.mn14:21.21: ‘Evaṁ sante āyasmāva gotamo sukhavihāritaro raññā māgadhena seniyena bimbisārenā’”ti.
root_text.mn14:21.23: Attamano mahānāmo sakko bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.mn14:0.2: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering
translation_text.mn14:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
translation_text.mn14:2.1: Then Mahānāma the Sakyan went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
translation_text.mn14:2.2: “For a long time, sir, I have understood your teaching like this:
translation_text.mn14:2.3: ‘Greed, hate, and delusion are corruptions of the mind.’
translation_text.mn14:2.6: Despite understanding this, sometimes my mind is occupied by thoughts of greed, hate, and delusion.
translation_text.mn14:2.8: I wonder what qualities remain in me that I have such thoughts?”
translation_text.mn14:3.1: “Mahānāma, there is a quality that remains in you that makes you have such thoughts.
translation_text.mn14:3.2: For if you had given up that quality you would not still be living at home and enjoying sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn14:3.3: But because you haven’t given up that quality you are still living at home and enjoying sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn14:4.1: Sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.
translation_text.mn14:4.2: So, Mahānāma, even though a noble disciple has clearly seen this with right wisdom, as long as they do not achieve the rapture and bliss that are apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities, or something even more peaceful than that,
translation_text.mn14:4.3: they can return to sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn14:4.4: But when they do achieve that rapture and bliss, or something more peaceful than that,
translation_text.mn14:4.5: they do not return to sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn14:5.1: Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I too clearly saw with right wisdom that:
translation_text.mn14:5.2: ‘Sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.’
translation_text.mn14:5.3: But so long as I didn’t achieve the rapture and bliss that are apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities, or something even more peaceful than that,
translation_text.mn14:5.4: I didn’t announce that I would not return to sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn14:5.5: But when I did achieve that rapture and bliss, or something more peaceful than that,
translation_text.mn14:5.6: I announced that I would not return to sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn14:6.1: And what is the gratification of sensual pleasures?
translation_text.mn14:6.2: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn14:6.4: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn14:6.8: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn14:6.9: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn14:6.10: The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation: this is the gratification of sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn14:7.1: And what is the drawback of sensual pleasures?
translation_text.mn14:7.2: It’s when a gentleman earns a living by means such as
translation_text.mn14:7.3: arithmetic, accounting, calculating, farming, trade, raising cattle, archery, government service, or one of the professions.
translation_text.mn14:7.4: But they must face cold and heat, being hurt by the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles, and risking death from hunger and thirst.
translation_text.mn14:7.5: This is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn14:8.1: That gentleman might try hard, strive, and make an effort, but fail to earn any money.
translation_text.mn14:8.2: If this happens, they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion, saying: ‘Oh, my hard work is wasted. My efforts are fruitless!’
translation_text.mn14:8.3: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn14:9.1: That gentleman might try hard, strive, and make an effort, and accrue money.
translation_text.mn14:9.2: But they experience pain and sadness when they try to protect it, thinking:
translation_text.mn14:9.3: ‘How can I prevent my wealth from being taken by rulers or bandits, consumed by fire, swept away by flood, or taken by unloved heirs?’
translation_text.mn14:9.4: And even though they protect it and ward it, rulers or bandits take it, or fire consumes it, or flood sweeps it away, or unloved heirs take it.
translation_text.mn14:9.5: They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion:
translation_text.mn14:9.7: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn14:10.1: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures kings fight with kings, aristocrats fight with aristocrats, brahmins fight with brahmins, and householders fight with householders. A mother fights with her child, child with mother, father with child, and child with father. Brother fights with brother, brother with sister, sister with brother, and friend fights with friend.
translation_text.mn14:10.2: Once they’ve started quarreling, arguing, and disputing, they attack each other with fists, stones, rods, and swords,
translation_text.mn14:10.3: resulting in death and deadly pain.
translation_text.mn14:10.4: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn14:11.1: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they don their sword and shield, fasten their bow and arrows, and plunge into a battle massed on both sides, with arrows and spears flying and swords flashing.
translation_text.mn14:11.2: There they are struck with arrows and spears, and their heads are chopped off,
translation_text.mn14:11.3: resulting in death and deadly pain.
translation_text.mn14:11.4: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn14:12.1: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they don their sword and shield, fasten their bow and arrows, and charge wetly plastered bastions, with arrows and spears flying and swords flashing.
translation_text.mn14:12.2: There they are struck with arrows and spears, splashed with dung, crushed by a superior force, and their heads are chopped off,
translation_text.mn14:12.3: resulting in death and deadly pain.
translation_text.mn14:12.4: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn14:13.1: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, and commit adultery.
translation_text.mn14:13.2: The rulers would arrest them and subject them to various punishments—
translation_text.mn14:13.3: whipping, caning, and clubbing; cutting off hands or feet, or both; cutting off ears or nose, or both; the ‘porridge pot’, the ‘shell-shave’, the ‘Rāhu’s mouth’, the ‘garland of fire’, the ‘burning hand’, the ‘bulrush twist’, the ‘bark dress’, the ‘antelope’, the ‘meat hook’, the ‘coins’, the ‘caustic pickle’, the ‘twisting bar’, the ‘straw mat’; being splashed with hot oil, being fed to the hounds, being impaled alive, and being beheaded.
translation_text.mn14:13.4: These result in death and deadly pain.
translation_text.mn14:13.5: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn14:14.1: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures, they conduct themselves badly by way of body, speech, and mind.
translation_text.mn14:14.2: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.mn14:14.3: This is a drawback of sensual pleasures to do with lives to come, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn14:15.1: Mahānāma, this one time I was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
translation_text.mn14:15.2: Now at that time several Jain ascetics on the slopes of Isigili at the Black Rock were constantly standing, turning down seats. And they felt painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion.
translation_text.mn14:16.1: Then in the late afternoon, I came out of retreat and went to the Black Rock to visit those Jain ascetics. I said to them,
translation_text.mn14:16.2: ‘Reverends, why are you constantly standing, turning down seats, so that you suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion?’
translation_text.mn14:17.1: When I said this, those Jain ascetics said to me,
translation_text.mn14:17.2: ‘Reverend, the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus:
translation_text.mn14:17.3: “Knowledge and vision are constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.”
translation_text.mn14:17.5: “O Jain ascetics, you have done bad deeds in a past life. Wear them away with these severe and grueling austerities.
translation_text.mn14:17.6: And when in the present you are restrained in body, speech, and mind, you’re not doing any bad deeds for the future.
translation_text.mn14:17.7: So, due to eliminating past deeds by fervent mortification, and not doing any new deeds, there’s nothing to come up in the future.
translation_text.mn14:17.8: With no future consequence, deeds end. With the ending of deeds, suffering ends. With the ending of suffering, feeling ends. And with the ending of feeling, all suffering will have been worn away.”
translation_text.mn14:17.9: We endorse and accept this, and we are satisfied with it.’
translation_text.mn14:18.1: When they said this, I said to them,
translation_text.mn14:18.3: for sure that you existed in the past, and it is not the case that you did not exist?’
translation_text.mn14:18.6: for sure that you did bad deeds in the past?’
translation_text.mn14:18.9: that you did such and such bad deeds?’
translation_text.mn14:18.12: that so much suffering has already been worn away? Or that so much suffering still remains to be worn away? Or that when so much suffering is worn away all suffering will have been worn away?’
translation_text.mn14:18.15: about giving up unskillful qualities in this very life and embracing skillful qualities?’
translation_text.mn14:19.1: ‘So it seems that you don’t know any of these things.
translation_text.mn14:19.8: That being so, when those in the world who are violent and bloody-handed and of cruel livelihood are reborn among humans they go forth as Jain ascetics.’
translation_text.mn14:20.1: ‘Reverend Gotama, pleasure is not gained through pleasure; pleasure is gained through pain.
translation_text.mn14:20.2: For if pleasure were to be gained through pleasure, King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha would gain pleasure, since he lives in greater pleasure than Venerable Gotama.’
translation_text.mn14:20.3: ‘Clearly the venerables have spoken rashly, without reflection.
translation_text.mn14:20.6: Rather, I’m the one who should be asked about
translation_text.mn14:20.7: who lives in greater pleasure, King Bimbisāra or Venerable Gotama?’
translation_text.mn14:20.8: ‘Clearly we spoke rashly and without reflection.
translation_text.mn14:20.10: But let that be. Now we ask Venerable Gotama:
translation_text.mn14:20.11: “Who lives in greater pleasure, King Bimbisāra or Venerable Gotama?”’
translation_text.mn14:21.1: ‘Well then, reverends, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.
translation_text.mn14:21.3: Is King Bimbisāra capable of experiencing perfect happiness for seven days and nights without moving his body or speaking?’
translation_text.mn14:21.6: Is King Bimbisāra capable of experiencing perfect happiness for six days …
translation_text.mn14:21.13: ‘But I am capable of experiencing perfect happiness for one day and night without moving my body or speaking.
translation_text.mn14:21.14: I am capable of experiencing perfect happiness for two days …
translation_text.mn14:21.20: What do you think, reverends? This being so, who lives in greater pleasure, King Bimbisāra or I?’
translation_text.mn14:21.21: ‘This being so, Venerable Gotama lives in greater pleasure than King Bimbisāra.’”
translation_text.mn14:21.22: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn14:21.23: Satisfied, Mahānāma the Sakyan approved what the Buddha said.
